q: What is an echocardiogram?
a: An echocardiogram, or 'echo', is a scan used to look at the heart and nearby blood vessels. It uses high-frequency sound waves to create images of the heart's structure and analyze blood flow.

q: Who can request an echocardiogram?
a: An echocardiogram can be requested by a heart specialist (cardiologist) or any doctor who suspects a heart problem.

q: What can an echocardiogram help diagnose?
a: An echocardiogram can help diagnose and monitor conditions such as heart attacks, heart failure, congenital heart disease, heart valve problems, cardiomyopathy, and endocarditis.

q: How is an echocardiogram carried out?
a: The most common type of echocardiogram is the transthoracic echocardiogram (TTE). It involves lying down on a bed, having small sensors attached to the chest, and a probe moved across the chest to create images.

q: What are the other types of echocardiograms?
a: Other types of echocardiograms include transoesophageal echocardiogram (TOE), stress echocardiogram, and contrast echocardiogram. Each type is used depending on the specific heart condition being assessed.

q: How long does an echocardiogram usually take?
a: An echocardiogram generally takes between 15 and 60 minutes to complete.

q: How are the results of an echocardiogram obtained?
a: The images from the echocardiogram are analyzed, and the results are usually sent to the doctor who requested the test. They will then discuss the results with the patient during a follow-up appointment.

q: Are there any risks or side effects of an echocardiogram?
a: A standard echocardiogram is a safe and painless procedure with no side effects. However, less common types of echocardiogram may have some discomfort or risks associated with them.

q: What are the risks of a transoesophageal echocardiogram (TOE)?
a: A TOE may cause discomfort and a sore throat afterward. Sedatives may be used, and driving should be avoided for 24 hours. There is a small risk of throat damage.

q: Can anyone have a contrast echocardiogram?
a: Some people with certain conditions or who take certain medicines may not be able to have a contrast echocardiogram due to potential side effects. It's best to consult with the doctor.

q: What is an echocardiogram?
a: An echocardiogram is a scan used to look at the heart and nearby blood vessels. It uses ultrasound waves to create images of the heart and can help diagnose and monitor certain heart conditions.

q: How does an echocardiogram work?
a: An echocardiogram uses high-frequency sound waves to create echoes when they bounce off different parts of the body. These echoes are turned into a moving image of the heart on a monitor.

q: Who can request an echocardiogram?
a: A heart specialist (cardiologist) or any doctor who suspects a problem with the heart can request an echocardiogram. This includes your GP.

q: What can an echocardiogram help diagnose?
a: An echocardiogram can help diagnose and monitor conditions such as heart damage from a heart attack, heart failure, congenital heart disease, problems with heart valves, cardiomyopathy, and endocarditis.

q: How is a transthoracic echocardiogram (TTE) carried out?
a: During a TTE, you will be asked to lie down on a bed and electrodes will be attached to your chest. A lubricating gel will be applied to your chest or directly to the ultrasound probe. The probe will be moved across your chest to capture images of your heart.

q: What other types of echocardiograms are there?
a: Other types of echocardiograms include transoesophageal echocardiogram (TOE), stress echocardiogram, and contrast echocardiogram. Each type is used depending on the specific heart condition and the required level of detail.

q: How long does an echocardiogram take?
a: The whole procedure usually takes between 15 and 60 minutes.

q: How will I receive the results of my echocardiogram?
a: In most cases, the results of the echocardiogram will be sent to the doctor who requested the test. Your doctor will then discuss the results with you during your next appointment.

q: Are there any risks or side effects associated with an echocardiogram?
a: A standard echocardiogram is a safe procedure with no side effects. However, less common types of echocardiograms may have some risks, such as discomfort during a TOE, chest pain during a stress echocardiogram, and possible side effects from contrast agents.

q: Are X-rays or CT scans used during an echocardiogram?
a: No, an echocardiogram does not involve the use of X-rays or CT scans. It uses ultrasound waves instead.
